p:
It is assumed that individuals are recruited (either through birth or migration) into the susceptible class at a rate
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\varLambda $$\end{document}
Λ
and die naturally with rate
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\mu $$\end{document}
μ
. Susceptible individuals get infected due to successful contacts with infectious or not perfectly isolated infected individuals at rate
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\lambda $$\end{document}
λ
. As a consequence, they become latent undetectable, who develop their state of infection to become latent detectable at rate
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\kappa _1$$\end{document}
κ 1
. We assume that the latent detectable class represent individuals whose viral load is above the detection limit of the PCR-based diagnostic test [ 7, 11]. Latent detectable individuals either are diagnosed and get isolated with probability
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$f_T$$\end{document}
f T
or develop symptoms to become infectious, who sequentially either get isolated at rate
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\alpha $$\end{document}
α
, or are removed from the system by recovery or Ebola-induced death at rate
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\gamma $$\end{document}
γ
. It is assumed here that Ebola-induced deaths occur for the infectious individuals with probability
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$q_1$$\end{document}
q 1
. Similarly, isolated individuals leave their class at rate
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\gamma _r$$\end{document}
γ r
, by either dying due to Ebola with probability
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$q_2$$\end{document}
q 2
, or they get recovered and become immune. It is assumed that isolation is partially effective so that successful contacts with susceptible individuals may lead to infection with probability r; this parameter is a measure of isolation effectiveness of infectious individuals. Thus, the force of infection is given by
1
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\begin{aligned} \lambda (t) = \frac{\beta [I(t) + (1-r)\ell J(t)]}{N(t) - r J(t)}. \end{aligned}$$\end{document}
λ
( t )
=
β [ I ( t ) + ( 1 - r ) ℓ J ( t ) ]
N ( t ) - r J ( t )
.
The assumptions mentioned above lead to the following model of equations
2
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\begin{aligned} \frac{dS}{dt}= & {} \varLambda - \lambda S - \mu S,\nonumber \\ \frac{dE_1}{dt}= & {} \lambda S - (\kappa _1 + \mu ) E_1,\nonumber \\ \frac{dE_2}{dt}= & {} \kappa _1 E_1 - (\kappa _2 + \mu ) E_2,\nonumber \\ \frac{dI}{dt}= & {} (1-f_T)\kappa _2 E_2 - (\alpha +\gamma + \mu ) I, \\ \frac{dJ}{dt}= & {} f_T \kappa _2 E_2 + \alpha I - (\gamma _r + \mu ) J,\nonumber \\ \frac{dR}{dt}= & {} (1-q_1) \gamma I + (1-q_2)\gamma _r J - \mu R \nonumber \end{aligned}$$\end{document}

\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\begin{aligned} N(t) = S(t) + E_1(t) + E_2(t) + I(t) + J(t) + R(t) \end{aligned}$$\end{document}

is the total population size at time t. On adding all equations of system ( 2) together, we get
3
